entry.title: SAP Business One for HANA Client Hangs Permanently on Loading Screen After Successful Credentials
entry.content:
1. System Environment

  • SAP B1 Version:

    SAP B1 10.0 VERSION for HANA & PL 02

  • Database: SAP HANA

    SAP HANA Enterprise Edition 2.0 SPS04 Rev 45 for B1

  • Deployment:

    On-Premise

2. Problem Description

After the user successfully enters credentials and selects the company database in the SAP Business One client, the client window opens but gets permanently stuck on the loading screen. The main application menu never appears.

  • No specific error message or timeout occurs; the process hangs indefinitely.

  • This issue affects all users and all client machines.

3. Steps to Reproduce

  1. Launch the SAP Business One client.

  2. Enter credentials and select the Company Database.

  3. Click OK.

  4. The application window opens and hangs on the loading screen indefinitely.

4. Detailed Troubleshooting Performed

We have executed the following checks, ruling out core database and server issues:

  • HANA Database Status: Verified that all core SAP HANA services (Indexserver, Nameserver, Daemon, etc.) are running and active (Green status). The relevant screenshot from the HANA Cockpit/Studio is attached.

  • B1 Service Health: Confirmed the License Manager Service, SLD Service, and B1iF/Service Layer are all running and restarted.

  • Server Load: Confirmed there is no unusual CPU or Memory utilization on either the HANA or B1 Application Server during the hang.

  • Add-On Bypass: We attempted to log in using the CTRL + SHIFT method to bypass Add-On initialization; the issue persists.

  • User/Role Check: The hang occurs for all users, including the B1 Superuser.

5. Conclusion & Request

The hang is likely occurring at the application layer during the B1 License validation, Cockpit loading, or interaction with an internal B1 service.

We require immediate support to resolve this issue.

Thank you for your urgent attention on this matter.

Best regards,

Sunil Patil

entry.title: Understanding Average Exception Aggregation in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Designing calculations is a core aspect of modeling in SAP Analytics Cloud. The platform offers a comprehensive set of functions, aggregations, and disaggregation techniques that allow modelers to implement business logic effectively. Within this toolbox, exception aggregation plays a key role by allowing modelers to control whether a measure is aggregated before or after formula calculations are applied. This blog focuses on the average-type exception aggregation, explains how each behaves,  and outlines the scenarios where they are most appropriate. 

There are four types of average exception aggregation, each defining a different way to select the members considered in the calculations.

Average

When to use: Choose ‚ÄúAverage‚Äù when you want to include NULL and zero values in the calculation.

In SAP Analytics Cloud, NULL values can occur for several reasons:  

  • They may originate from imported data containing empty records.
  • More commonly, NULLs are created implicitly when another measure is booked for the same combination of dimension members. For example, if Measure A is unbooked for a given intersection (Date ‚Äú2025-01‚Äù, Project ‚ÄúPRJ-001‚Äù) but Measure B is booked, SAC assigns a NULL to Measure A for that same combination of dimension members.
  • They can also arise in calculated measures, such as formulas that return NULL, or a restricted measure used in the story with a filter outside its restriction interval. For example, if a measure is restricted to 2025 but the table shows all years, the non-2025 years will return NULL.

Understanding this behavior is important because NULL values influence how averages are calculated. Under the ‚ÄúAverage‚Äù exception aggregation, NULLs increase the count of members in the denominator, even though they do not contribute to the sum. As a result, the final average may differ from what is expected, particularly when measures follow different booking patterns.

NULL and UNBOOKED are not the same. UNBOOKED indicates an empty state, where no record exists. NULL, on the other hand, is a technical value used by SAP Analytics Cloud to represent missing values for a given record/dimension combination, such as when a record/row exists because another measure has a booked value for the same combination. This difference can be observed in the fact view under Model ‚Üí Data Foundation: Unbooked rows are not shown at all, while NULL cells are explicitly displayed as (NULL).

Average excl. NULL

When to use: Choose ‚ÄúAverage excl. NULL‚Äù when you want to exclude NULL values from the calculation.

This option ensures that only members with booked values contribute to the average. NULL values are ignored, preventing the booked state from another measure influencing the calculation.

Example

The following example illustrates how "Average" and "Average excl. NULL" produce different results. This scenario uses a simplified planning model in which Capacity Hours, Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0), and Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. Null) measures are maintained for the same Project-Role combination. 

  • Capacity Hours represents the monthly staffing capacity available for the given project/role.
  • Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0) shows the actual hours worked/booked and is aggregated using the ‚ÄúAverage‚Äù exception aggregation.
  • Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. Null) shows the same underlying consumption data as Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0) but is aggregated using ‚ÄúAverage excl. NULL‚Äù.

Figure 1. Comparison of Consumed Hours aggregated with "Average" and "Average excl. NULL". February is counted under "Average" but excluded under "Average excl. NULL".

Observed results in Q1 (2025):

  • Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0) divides the total hours from January and March by all three months in the horizon, including Feb (2025), where there is no activity.
  • Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. Null) divides the total by only the months with recorded hours, producing the expected results for this scenario.

Why the difference, and what do the empty values in Feb (2025) represent?

As shown in the screenshot below, taken from the planning model's Data Foundation, the empty cells for the Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0) and Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. Null) are assigned with NULLs. This happens because Capacity Hours is booked for the same Project-Role-Period combination. As a result: 

  • Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0) counts Feb (2025)
  • Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. Null) ignores Feb (2025)

Figure 2. Viewing NULL values in the Model ‚Üí Data Foundation.

Which aggregation is correct?

Before deciding, we need to clarify the business intention for aggregating consumed hours:

  • Case A: exclude months with no activity
  • Case B: include months with no activity

Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. NULL) produces the correct result for Case A, where months without activity should be excluded.

Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. NULL, 0) may appear correct at first glance for Case B, but its result only aligns with expectations in isolated situations rather than consistently. To understand why, look at what happens when we remove Capacity Hours from February (2025). Removing this value also removes February from the display when the table is set to hide unbooked members. In this state, Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. NULL, 0) returns 240, which is the sum of the booked values from January and March divided by two. The key observation is that the Average type no longer considers February, simply because the record is unbooked rather than NULL. In other words, the same measure, the same dimension combination, and the same consumption pattern produce different results depending on whether the data state was NULL or unbooked.

Figure 3. Removing Capacity Hours from February converts the period from NULL to Unbooked. With no record present, "Average" no longer counts February.

Figure 4. Unbooked period disappears from display when Show Unbooked is turned off.

To fulfill Case B correctly and consistently, the appropriate configuration is not ‚ÄúAverage‚Äù but ‚ÄúAverage incl. Unbooked‚Äù. This ensures that all periods in the horizon are counted, regardless of whether they are booked, null, or unbooked. See the ‚ÄúAverage incl. Unbooked‚Äù section of this blog post.

The use of ‚ÄúAverage‚Äù (i.e., including Null, 0) should therefore be limited to scenarios where the effects of NULL are intentional and understood. When there is no such explicit use case, another type of average exception aggregation should be used.

Below are examples of cases where such dependencies are purposeful, and the presence of a booked measure determines whether a period should be counted in the average.

  • If a Subscription Fee is booked for a month, that month must be counted when computing averages such as Monthly API Calls or Active Subscription Usage, even if there is no usage.
  • The existence of a Promotion Price or Promotion Flag defines the eligibility of that period. Because the promotion was available to the market, that time window must be counted when calculating averages such as Monthly Sales.

Average excl. 0, NULL

When to use: Choose ‚ÄúAverage excl. 0, NULL‚Äù when you want to exclude both zero and NULL values from the calculation.

In addition to excluding NULLs, this exception aggregation also skips members booked with a zero. This is helpful when zero should not serve as a valid observation. Typical examples include KPIs where zero indicates ‚Äúno measurement taken,‚Äù rather than a real data point.

Average incl. Unbooked

When to use: Choose ‚ÄúAverage incl. Unbooked‚Äù when you want the calculation also to consider Unbooked members. Compared to ‚ÄúAverage‚Äù, this exception aggregation treats any absence of value the same, regardless of whether the cell is technically stored as NULL or is completely unbooked.

This behavior makes ‚ÄúAverage incl. Unbooked‚Äù suitable for use cases such as period-based KPIs, where the entire time horizon matters. For example, when calculating an average headcount for a year, you may want the denominator to include all twelve months, not just the months where headcount was recorded.

Extending the Example 

To illustrate the behavior more clearly, let‚Äôs extend the previous scenario by adding:

  • Consumed Hours (Average incl. Unbooked)
  • A second project: PRJ-002

Both projects share the booked data pattern, except that PRJ-002 has no Capacity Hours in Feb (2025). Because no measure is booked at that intersection, Feb (2025) is fully Unbooked for PRJ-002.

Figure 5. Extending the example with PRJ-002 demonstrates the difference between NULL and Unbooked. "Average incl. Unbooked" counts all periods, while "Average" includes only periods with a NULL.

What the results show:

  • Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null) produces different Q1 averages between PRJ-001 and PRJ-002, even though the underlying booked hours are identical. The difference exists because NULL is counted, while Unbooked is not.
  • Consumed Hours (Average incl. Unbooked) returns identical Q1 averages across both projects, because the denominator counts all months regardless of whether they contain booked, NULL, or unbooked values.

"Average incl. Unbooked" exception aggregation is the correct choice for Case B (include months with no activity), while "Average" behaves correctly only if those empty periods happen to be represented in the model as NULL rather than unbooked.

Summary

Exception Aggregation in SAP Analytics Cloud is a powerful mechanism that determines how measures roll up across dimensions. While average-type exception aggregation appears simple, its handling of NULL, zero, and unbooked members can change the result in ways that are not always intended.

Use ‚ÄúAverage‚Äù only when the inclusion of NULL values is intentional and aligned with the business logic. It should not be selected by default. In most planning and reporting scenarios, the other three average-types ("Average excl. NULL", "Average excl. 0, NULL", or "Average incl. Unbooked") provide the expected behavior for the use case. By evaluating how NULLs are generated, whether they should be included in the average, and whether empty periods represent inactivity or a true absence, modelers can choose the appropriate average-type and ensure that their KPIs return results that reflect the intended business logic and that users can trust.

entry.title: How to Learn and Get Certified with SAP HANA Calculation View Modeling
entry.content:
SAP HANA Cloud, and SAP HANA Platform (on-premise) is a very popular solution for data management, with its powerful in-memory technology and a data model that fits a variety of data categories, including spatial, graph, unstructured data, and many more.

Calculation Views are the recommended approach to reporting efficiently on SAP HANA data using models that you design with a graphical user interface. To get an introduction to SAP HANA Calculation Views, read Jan ZWICKEL‚Äôs blog.

So how can you become proficient in SAP HANA Calculation Views modeling?

Calculation View Modeling belongs to the role Data Engineer - SAP HANA. In addition to Calculation View Modeling, this role also involves knowledge of SAP HANA Data Provisioning using technologies such as SAP HANA Smart Data Access (SDA) and SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI).

The following diagram shows the Data Engineer role responsibilities compared with the Data Analyst/Data Scientist role.

 SAP HANA Cloud or SAP HANA Platform (On-Premise)?

As you might know already, SAP HANA Cloud is the technology on which SAP invests heavily, so most of the innovation is made in the cloud version, so that is where you should start if you are a beginner so that you are learning the latest features. But we also maintain a curriculum for SAP HANA On-Premise.

Let's checkout the course offerings:

SAP HANA Cloud SAP HANA On-PremiseCourse Purpose
HC300 - Developing Data Models in SAP HANA CloudHA300 - SAP HANA ModelingCover SAP HANA Calculation Views with a comprehensive course that also covers the practical aspects of the HDI Deployment Infrastructure (accessing external data, etc.)
HAHC55 - Provisioning Data to SAP HANAHAHC55 - Provisioning Data to SAP HANADiscuss native provisioning techniques of SAP HANA (Cloud and On-Premise), and covers virtualization, data replication and data transformation

These courses offer solid, theoretical knowledge, illustrations, and are complemented by demos by an instructor (HA300 instructor-led training) or recorded demos (HA300 self-study, HC300 and HAHC55).

What if I want to practice?

Here again, we have you covered!

The HA300 course is offered as an instructor-led training where you can work through lots of exercises on a provided SAP system. The HC300 and HAHC55 courses have fully configured SAP Practice Systems available, where you can quickly spin-up your own system, or access an existing system (depending on type of course and role) where you can practice a using the similar exercises that we have in the instructor-lead class. To access SAP Practice Systems you need a subscription to the SAP learning portal : learning.sap.com).

Note:  for a course such as HC300, your system is generally accessible a couple of minutes after you enrolled.

Want to learn how to access practice systems? Just click below:

  • HC300 - Developing Data Models with SAP HANA Cloud 

Live Sessions

In addition to courses and practice systems, the SAP Learning portal offers live sessions that are useful to go keep learning, ask questions, deepen your knowledge on specific topics. These sessions are delivered by subject-matter-experts (SMEs), either from SAP Training, SAP Partners or other experts at SAP such as Product Managers.

The sessions come under five categories:

  • Get Started
  • Expert Deep Dive
  • What's New
  • Get Certified
  • Stay Certified

Some of the live sessions are available for free, some require a subscription. This is visible in the example below:

SAP HANA Cloud Live Session catalog sample on SAP Learning 

So, ready for the big jump?

When you feel prepared enough, it's time to take the certification exam.

On this topic, there is some news. SAP is moving its certification model towards practice-based exams which will replace traditional theoretical/knowledge-based exams (multi-choice questions), starting January 1st 2026. Some pilot exams are already available since the beginning of November 2025.

To conclude, we are looking forward to getting your feedback on these resources aimed at getting your level higher in the area of SAP HANA Cloud modeling. Please feel free to use this new community and connect with us and other learners. Also let us know about topics you would like to have covered in future live sessions, so that we can make our content even more suited to your needs.

Happy learning with SAP!
Alain

entry.title: SAP ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx v1.5.0 released
entry.content:
On December 5, 2025, IBM has released version 1.5.0 of its ABAP¬Æ Software Development Kit (SDK) for IBM¬Æ watsonx‚Ñ¢ services. The watsonx.ai service can be used to train, validate, tune, and deploy foundation and machine learning models. The watsonx.ai Runtime is used to build, run and manage generative AI and machine learning applications with built-in performance and scalability. The ABAP SDK provides a class library that can be downloaded to SAP systems using abapGit and comes in two flavors:

  • ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx, using SAP NetWeaver for the SAP Business Suite running on SAP NetWeaver 7.50 or above and for the SAP S/4HANA on-premises edition.
  • ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx, using SAP BTP ABAP Environment for the SAP Business Technology Platform ABAP Environment.

Enhancements in this release include new watsonx.ai methods for the categories Notebooks and Notebook Versions. More information about the changes in version 1.5.0 can be found in the repositories in the MIGRATION-V1.5.0.md  migration document.

Detailed information on how to setup and use the SDK can be found in the README.md files of the GitHub repositories. The README.md files also provide two comprehensive examples to show how the supported services can be used. An even more elaborated article about how use watsonx services with the ABAP SDK can be found in Joachim Rese's blog article How to Bring Generative AI to Your ABAP Program Using the ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx.

entry.title: Use of DSEDIT tool to create entry in sql.ini file for Sybase ASE database
entry.content:
SAP Data Services installation stalls as the installer is unable to identify the CMS and Audit repositories.

Environment for this installation setup

  • Product - SAP Data Services 4.3 
  • Database - Sybase ASE 16.0
  • Operating system - Windows Server 2019 Standard

Initial investigation took us to the ODBC connections and it worked fine and successfully connected to the respective database repositories. However on deeper analysis, it was observed that for the backend Sybase ASE database the connection doesn‚Äôt utilizes the ODBC connectors, it requires a Sybase client to be installed on the application machine and the resulting sql.ini file needs to be updated with the entries for CMS and AUDIT repositories.

SAP Data Services or Business Intelligence installation on Sybase ASE database needs the following client to be installed on the application host

After the installation below shown "sql.ini" file is created which needs to be amended with the entries of the repositories required for connection.

 

The format for the entries are

[CMS]
master=TCP,<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>
query=TCP,<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>

[AUDIT]
master=<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>
query=TCP,<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>

 

Another way of updating the sql.ini file is to use the DSEDIT tool provided by the client.

Launch the tool with administrator access

Click Ok

Click on the ServerObject and select Add

Enter the name of the repository, this should be exactly the same which will be used in the installation, in this example ‚ÄúCMS‚Äù

Double click on the server address bar on the right and click on the add button

On the TCP protocol in the network address bar enter the hostname/IP address followed by the port number at which the Sybase ASE DB is reachable separated by a comma

Once the entry is added test the connection

Right click and select Ping Server

Click on Ping

A connect succeeded message will prove the connection is successfully established, and an entry will get created in the sql.ini file with right syntax and parameters.

Now the installer will identify the CMS and AUDIT database repositories

entry.title: Discovery Package: Test, Demo, and Development for SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
Many partners have asked for a systems for testing, demos, and development of cloud-exclusive innovations such as AI capabilities, and Joule in a private cloud environment. Therefore we expanded our portfolio by introducing the Test, Demo and Development for SAP Cloud ERP Private, Discovery Package.

The Cloud ERP Private Discovery Package 2025 Release will be launched on December 12, 2025.

It is currently available only to partners, with more information and the ordering process provided on the central landing page in the Partner Portal.
 

What is the SAP Cloud ERP Private Discovery Package?

The Discovery Package is the SAP Cloud ERP Private successor to the on-premise SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance. It provides a SAP Cloud ERP Private system with:

- SAP S/4HANA core scope
- pre-activated Best Practice content
- additional demo scenarios
- a rich collection of continuously updated demo guides
- the option to connect your BTP account for Joule services

You can adjust configurations as needed and unlock additional scope (e.g. via business functions) if the required software components are installed‚Äîfully documented as part of the offering. The system is ideal for use cases like Fit-to-Standard analyses, exploring and demonstrating Cloud Private innovations and adding custom configurations to showcase extensions.
The system includes multiple clients for the different use cases:
- Client 000 ‚Äì SAP Reference Client
- Client 100 ‚Äì Preconfigured demo scenarios
- Client 200 ‚Äì Activate content yourself
- Client 400 ‚Äì Compare Best Practices across localizations

Key Benefits

Build and showcase your SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions to customers in your own dedicated system
Use a pre-configured SAP Cloud ERP Private system to develop your own content and test and demo SAP Cloud ERP solutions to your customers.

Explore and tailor the system to your business needs
Use curated demo guides to walk through activated best practices and extend scenarios. Customize users, content, and processes freely. Replace the system anytime with the latest version.

Leverage ready-to-use content with AI and Joule integration
Benefit from activated best practices, enriched demo data, and evolving curated guides. Discover how embedded AI and Joule enhance business processes and decision-making.

Seamlessly integrate with your SAP BTP environment
Unlock the full potential of SAP Business AI and other SAP BTP services by connecting your system with your SAP BTP account.

Develop and extend with clean core principles
Support modern development workflows including GitHub integration, SAINT for add-ons, and side-by-side extensions via BTP. Maintain a clean core while innovating flexibly.

Launch quickly with self services in SAP for Me
Experience efficient service provisioning and management with SAP for Me. Stay agile Stay agile with a self-service approach that allows for direct action.

Some Specifics

Refer to the Getting Started Guide for detailed information.

System Access
From local computers, the TDD system can be accessed via HTTPS only:
- SAP WebGUI, SAP Fiori Launchpad, and other HTTPS-enabled UI components of S/4
- ABAP Development Tools (ADT) via HTTPS-enabled logon
This ensures secure connectivity and compliance with cloud security standards.

Development Scope
‚Ä¢ Tooling:
- WebGUI-based transactions (e.g., SE38/SE80; no ABAP Debugger)
- ADT (including debugging view and more)
‚Ä¢ Partners are responsible for transferring development artifacts (git-based CTS recommended).
‚Ä¢ Add-on Assembly Kit is available but offered separately by ICC.
‚Ä¢ SAP Notes and other non-OS-based patches can be applied with an entitled partner S-User.

Provisioning and Management with SAP for Me

Ordering is simple: Place your request via Partner Portal, and the system will appear in SAP for Me once the order is booked. Provisioning takes about 90 minutes. For security place your IP ranges and then the system is ready to use.

By default, we provision a Cloud Private system with the latest version, which will be Cloud ERP Private 2025 as of December 12.
If you already have the 2023 FPS03 version of the Discovery Package running, you can simply reprovision from the 2025 template in SAP for Me‚Äîno need to go through the ordering process again.
We release a new version with every Feature Pack Stack (FPS) or general release, and you can reprovision to newer versions under the same subscription. You can also run multiple subscriptions in parallel.

In SAP for Me, you can also trigger service requests such as:
- Restrict Access (mandatory)
- System Reboot
- System Reprovisioning
- System Backup (weekly backups included)
- System Restore from Backup
- Enable ABAP Namespace for Development

The Discovery Package will continue to evolve, with additional use cases and capabilities planned for future releases.

entry.title: Embedded Analytics for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 - List of Available Tables Reporting & Dashboard
entry.content:
SAP Sales & Service Cloud Version 2 (V2) introduces a modernized approach to analytics by embedding SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) directly into the platform. This integration provides powerful reporting and dashboard capabilities without relying on external tools, enabling real-time insights and advanced visualization options.

Note :
Embedded Analytics provided in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 is based on the embedded edition of SAP Analytics Cloud (eSAC). It is not the full version of SAP Analytics Cloud and therefore offers a limited set of functionalities compared to the standalone SAC solution.

What is Embedded Analytics in V2?

Unlike previous versions, V2 does not have native analytics. Instead, it leverages SAP Analytics Cloud, embedded edition (eSAC) as the single analytics engine across SAP solutions. This ensures:

  • Unified reporting experience across Sales and Service processes.
  • Real-time data analysis using standard C4C data sources.
  • Advanced visualization options like charts, tables, KPIs, and interactive dashboards.

Key Features

  • Design Stories Workcenter for administrators to create dashboards.
  • Analysis Workcenter for end-users to view and interact with stories.
  • Role-based access for personalized reporting.
  • Calculated Columns & Filters for custom metrics.
  • Single Sign-On (SSO) for secure access to eSAC

Available Data Sources & Tables

Embedded SAC uses the same standard data sources as native Business Analytics in C4C. These include:

  • Opportunity Data (Forecast vs. Actuals)
  • Account & Contact Information
  • Activity & Interaction Logs
  • Service Tickets / Cases (Status, Escalation, Source Channels)
  • Sales Orders & Quotes
  • Lead Management Data
  • Product & Pricing Tables

Each data source can be extended with:

  • Filters (e.g., by region, status, time frame)
  • Calculated Columns (e.g., revenue variance, SLA compliance)
  • Aggregations for KPIs.

Reporting & Dashboard Capabilities

With embedded SAC, you can:

  • Build Stories combining charts, tables, and text.
  • Create Numeric Charts for KPIs like Open Tickets or Revenue.
  • Use Color Coding & Conditional Formatting for better insights.
  • Enable Drill-down Analysis for detailed exploration.
  • Share dashboards securely across teams

Benefits for Sales & Service Teams

  • Sales Managers can track pipeline health, forecast accuracy, and order conversion.
  • Service Managers can monitor ticket resolution times, escalation trends, and customer satisfaction.
  • Executives get consolidated dashboards for strategic decision-making.

Available Tables for Reporting & Dashbaord

Available Table NamesTechncial Name
Individual Customerindividualcustomerservice_individualCustomer_view
Volume Pipeline(Extension)volumepipelineservice_pipeline_ext_view
Sales Quote Headersalesquoteservice_salesQuote_view
Topic Analyzer Analytical Modelmlnlptopicanalyzerservice_caseTopicAnalysisResult_view

entry.title: How to properly configure SAP CAP MCP Server so Codex can detect it?
entry.content:
I'm trying to configure Codex to detect and use the SAP CAP MCP Server, but Codex keeps saying that no MCP server is running, even though I can start it manually and see it listening on a port.

Here is what I tried so far:

mcp.json

{
"servers": {
"cds-mcp": {
"command": "npx",
"args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
"env": {},
"type": "stdio"
}
},
"inputs": []
}

 

The SAP CAP MCP server appears to run correctly (screenshot attached), but Codex still reports:

config.toml (Codex)

[tools.mcp-server-cap]
type = "mcp"
command = "cds-mcp"
args = ["--port", "4005"]

 

Question

Has anyone managed to configure Codex with the CAP MCP server?
Is there something obvious I'm missing. Perhaps related to TCP vs STDIO mode or how Codex expects MCP servers to be declared?

Any help or working example would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Budget EAC/ ETC for entreprise projects in SAP S/4HAN...
entry.content:
Good day @hajersoula 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/93bd0b1e72ca4cbcbfb942d4497529f7/170565565a0f4b30873b6bb1b6e66b3d.html?locale=en-US

This blog provides some insights: Project Budget Availability Control Profile ‚Äì Time Range

To summarise, your observations are correct. The current public cloud does not provide native EAC/ETC feature in Enterprise Projects nor does it do for a direct UI for manual initial budget.

The best practices I suggest is:

For EAC/ETC Calculation:

Use SAP Analytics Cloud or create a Custom CDS Views to compute and visualise the desired EAC/ETC metrics. These can include actuals, commitments and planned values.

For your Initial Budge Entry:

  • The standard approach is through CSV when you use the import Financial Plan Data app.

There is no supported User Interface method for manual entry but you may consider templates to simplify your process.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Gift Card / Voucher Support for SAP Commerce Cloud + S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Äì Partner Options?
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

We are currently designing our architecture using:

  • SAP Commerce Cloud for storefronts / customer ordering

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud as ERP and financial system

  • SAP BTP for integrations and workflow

One gap we are running into is native gift card / voucher functionality across this stack. Our requirement includes:

  • Creation of gift cards or voucher codes

  • Balance tracking and redemption across multiple orders

  • Integration with Commerce Cloud checkout

  • Proper financial posting in S/4HANA (deferred revenue, redemption, breakage)

From what we can tell, there is no fully standard, out-of-the-box solution today that works end-to-end for this scenario.

I wanted to ask the community:

  1. Are there any SAP-certified partners or add-on solutions commonly used to provide gift card / stored value functionality with SAP Commerce Cloud + S/4HANA Public Cloud?

  2. Are there any SAP roadmap items for native gift card support in Commerce Cloud or S/4HANA Public Cloud?

We are trying to stay as close to standard as possible and avoid heavy customization where feasible.

Any shared experience or recommendations would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Incorrect Decimal Conversion SD_SDOC_PRINT01
entry.content:
Hi,

we are experiencing an issue with decimal formatting in our SD forms for customers outside Germany. For example, a customer from the Netherlands should see "1.234,56" but instead receives the US format "1,234.56".

 

I traced the problem with SFP tracing and inspected the pdfDocument.xml inside the generated PDF. The file contains <locale>de_NL</locale>, which is an invalid locale combination. I suspect the system falls back to the en_US locale, which explains the US-style number formatting.

 

When I set ls_docparams-langu to 'N', pdfDocument.xml shows <locale>nl_NL</locale> and the decimal formatting on the PDF is correct. Note: ls_docparams-langu gets its value from gs_nast-spras.

I think I'm missing a tiny step to solve this but I don't know where to go from here now.

entry.title: RAP DETERMINATION handler METHOD stuck in Infinite recursive calls to itself because of MODIFY EML
entry.content:
Hello Gurus,

The issue we are facing is exactly the same as,

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/determination-on-save-infinite-loop-issue-rap/qaq-p/12784660

and unfortunately we had to go with the same workaround, which doesn't seems to be legit approach. And as mentioned over one of the comments there, I also have the same concern,

Details of the issue we are facing : 

Below 3 fields are part of the RAP BO we have,

In the Behavior Definition we have maintained a DETERMINATION for the OnHoldQuantity field changes as shown below,

// determination set_allocation_status on save { update; create; field Allocation_In_hand, status; }

  determination set_allocation_status on save { update; create; field OnHoldQuantity; }

And below is the Implementation of this DETERMINATION handler METHOD set_allocation_status.

It can be noted that as part of this MODIFY EML we are modifying only allocation_in_hand and status fields of the Entity.

But once the Execution Control reaches this MODIFY EML, again it calls back the DETERMINATION code which we have maintained for OnHoldQuantity field and this cycle continues indefinitely. 

Even though we fixed this issue as per the workaround mentioned in the referenced thread, buy making use of a Helper Class with a Static Attribute which acts as a flag for the MODIFY action executed at first place. 

But, this doesn't seem to be a legit workaround and rather I guess we need to have some Syntax addition using which we can tell the system that it should be executed only once.

Equally Strange is that even though the DETERMINATION is set for OnHoldQuantity field and in the MODIFY EML we are changing other fields still this DETERMINATION meant for OnHoldQuantity field is getting triggered.

If I am missing anything here, requesting to pour in your thoughts.

Helpful suggestions much appreciated.

Thanks,

Sijin

entry.title: Calculate price with null values
entry.content:
Hi,

I have a table in SAC with prices per Product group in each month/year. For actual price values equal to zero or null, I want that the system takes the last month with a price value. The first table in the below screenshot is the actual version. The other table should illustrate the expected result.

For the product group "Baugruppen" the system takes the price of 100 from January and put it into the remaining months of the year (feb - dec). For the product group "RM" the price for jan - apr is 0 because there was no price in a previous month of the year. The price of jul and aug is 130 because it takes the price of jun. And the price of Oct - Dec is 130 because it takes the price of Sep.

Is there a way to implement this logic in SAC with story or model capabilities e.g. calculated measures or anything else, without using planning activities like data actions. Even if there is a way during import in the wrangling process, it would be helpful.

Thanks and kind regards,

Dustin

entry.title: Re: Adding Additional Fields in Decision Table of BRF+ Ap...
entry.content:
@Saswata89 Sorry I am two years late to the party, but  honestly, even at this point, I have to say SAP hasn't really gone out of the way when it comes to OPD and BRF+ to allow flexibility for customers to adjust output management as they want to. 

I went through the same motions and arrived at the same problem.

At least this is my solution to the problem. 

 

#1 I don't want to add implicit enhancements to the system BUT by adding a POST exit to the method IF_FDT_APPLICATION_SETTINGS~GET_CHANGEABILITY in class CL_APOC_BRF_SETTINGS I opened the OPD_V3_BILLING_DOCUMENT application for editing in the development system. This gives me much needed flexibility to add custom expressions and such. 

#2 Now I can go to brf+ , navigate to the OPD_V3_BILLING_DOCUMENT application and adjust the Procedure call PC_GET_TRANSIENT_DATA by using my custom wrapper class around CL_FDP_V3_BD_TRANS_DATA_HELPER class. The wrapper calls the same methods of CL_FPD_V3_BD_TRANS_DATA_HELPER but for GET_TRANSIENT_DATA_BRF method, I populate the extra fields I've added. 

Alternatively, if you don't want to make changes to the BRF+ application, you can add an implicit enhancement to the GET_TRANSIENT_DATA_BRF method. 

I have to ask SAP as well. Is this is the only way ? 

Why cannot SAP expose some of the nicer badis ES_APOC_UTILITY and ES_APOC_CONFIGURATION for customer use that may solve a lot of problems for us. 

Best Regards,
Tharindu W

entry.title: Re: Create a Document in /SAPSLL/LEGDOC table with updati...
entry.content:
Hi,

Why do you want to use a BAPI or FM to update the table?
The question is quite generic.
The /SAPSLL/LEGDOC (Customs Document: Documents) is used for Documents, e.g. Document Determination.

So it is filled, e.g. with Data Default for Customs Documents, or Documents from Determination Strategies (Measures).
If you want to extend some things with development, you can use Interface /SAPSLL/IF_EX_CUHD_PROP e.g. for items with Method ITEM_DATA_PROPOSE (Propose Item Data for Customs Shipment/Declaration)

I hope that helps.

SAP Global Trade Services

entry.title: Configuring Essential Tasks in SAP Commerce Cloud via the Backoffice Administration Cockpit
entry.content:
I'm Charis from SAP CX Product Learning team and I am happy to share some exciting news for SAP Commerce Cloud business users and consultants! A brand-new course has arrived on learning.sap.com:

Configuring Essential Tasks in SAP Commerce Cloud via the Backoffice Administration Cockpit 

Who actually needs this course?

This beginner-level course is designed for business users and consultants who wish to build their foundational skills in SAP Commerce Cloud administration. This course is part of a dedicated learning series aimed at supporting business users and consultants throughout their SAP Commerce Cloud journey. The total duration of the course is approximately 3 hours.

Learning Objectives

After completing this course, learners will be able to to configure SAP Commerce Cloud by performing typical administrative tasks in the Backoffice Administration Cockpit. More specifically, the course consists of 5 units:
  • Configuring Essential Functionality in Backoffice: In this unit, learners will identify the various GUI areas within the Backoffice and understand their purposes. Additionally, they will receive a high-level introduction to Backoffice configuration tools, such as Provided Perspectives and Orchestrator, and explore the reasons why different companies or businesses might require customization.
  • Managing Users and Their Access Rights and Restrictions: This unit teaches learners how to manage users, including configuring their access rights and restrictions within the Backoffice.
  • Ensuring that Business Users Enter Valid Values in SAP Commerce Cloud User Interfaces: After completing this unit, learners will be able to explain validation support in SAP Commerce Cloud UIs for ensuring correct data input, as well as perform common validation configurations in Backoffice.
  • Working with Workflows: This unit explores the features and functions of the workflow collaboration center UI.
  • Automating Actions in SAP Commerce Cloud: This unit explains how to use cronjobs and tasks to automate performance of administrative operations in Backoffice.

The course contains very informative content provided in text, diagrams, videos. At the end of each unit, you will be called to answer on quiz questions which will test your understanding on the topic.

The course is available for everyone and it's free! Complete this course and earn a verifiable SAP Authorized Badge on your learning profile!

entry.title: SAP DMC - Data Migration object becomes unusable to load in development system after TR release
entry.content:
Hi, In the SAP Data Migration Cockpit, a project is created with its migration objects, assigned to a package and transport, and then moved to Quality. However, once the transport is released, I am no longer able to use the migration object for loading data in the Development system. Is this expected behaviour? I would assume not.

In our current S/4HANA 2023 system, while the object remains in change mode and is assigned to an open transport, it is available for data loading in the Fiori Migrate Your Data app. But after the transport is released, the object status changes to Not Ready for Processing and all load-related options become greyed out.

This raises a concern ‚Äî how are we expected to perform test loads in Development (for new requirements or on-demand testing) if the object becomes unusable after a transport release? These projects and objects were already created and moved to Quality before I joined, but the process of creating a project, adding objects, and assigning transports should behave consistently across environments.

Could you please advise what might be missing in our setup, or whether there is a configuration aspect we need to review? Any guidance would be much appreciated.

Modify entities of <<RootEntity>> IN LOCAL MODE
Entity <<EntityName>>
update fields ( <<Field Name>>)
with Value #( for <<lw_workarea>> in <<lt_internal_table>> ( %tky = <<lw_workarea>>-%tky
              field = <<lw_workarea>>-field     )
     ).
if this didn't work, please check with internal action <<action_name>>.

entry.title: Re: Transport a printer deletion
entry.content:
Hello,

You can delete output devices (printers) using a transport request. This is documented in 64337 - Transporting output devices (printers) - SAP for Me

Steps:

  1. Identify the Output Device

    • Go to transaction SPAD.
    • Note down the name of the output device you want to delete.

  2. Delete the Output Device

    • In SPAD, delete the printer from the system.

  3. Create a Transport Request

    • Go to transaction SE09.
    • Create a Workbench Transport Request.

  4. Add the Object Manually

    • Double-click your transport request.
    • Add the object with the following details:
      • Program ID: R3TR
      • Object Type: SPDV
      • Object Name: [Output Device Name]

  5. Release the Transport

    • When you release this transport and import it into the next system, the specified output device will be deleted there as well.

entry.title: SuccessFactors 2H 2025: Seamless Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment
entry.content:
What‚Äôs New?

SAP SuccessFactors introduces a powerful enhancement via the new feature Transfer Individual Talent Data from Inactive to Active Employment:

"Transfer Individual Talent Data from Inactive to Active Employment"- This enhancement introduces a person-centric Manage Individual Talent Data Transfer capability, enabling administrators to seamlessly migrate an employee‚Äôs complete talent history in a single action from inactive to active employment. 

Key Highlights

The new functionality inaugurates an advanced functionality within SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals, facilitating the seamless migration of an individual‚Äôs complete historical talent data from an inactive employment record to their current active employment in a single, streamlined process. This ensures uninterrupted continuity of performance insights across employment transitions, thereby supporting holistic talent management and organizational agility.

Business Use Cases

When an employee permanently relocates to a host country, a new user ID is assigned to them. During this transition, the employee requires access to their talent data originally associated with their home country user ID. In such instances, administrators or HR personnel can facilitate the seamless transfer of the employee‚Äôs talent data from their inactive home country user ID to the newly active host country user ID, ensuring uninterrupted access to their complete talent history.

How to Configure

  1. You have enabled Employee Central to manage multiple employments.
  2. You have enabled at least one of these modules: Goal Management, Performance Management, 360 Reviews, Continuous Performance Management, Calibration, and Career Development.
  3. You have enabled the data transfer tool through Admin Center > Company System and Logo Settings > Enable Individual Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment.
  4. You're recommended to configure employment differentiators, which helps you identify and select the correct source and target employments for data transfer.
  5. The subject person for data transfer should have at least one inactive employment and one active employment.
  6. To ensure the person's new employment and their stakeholders have the permission to access the transferred data, make sure module-specific permissions are correctly granted with right target population. For details, refer to the Guide topic in the Related Information section.

Role-Based Permission Pre-requisites

  1. With the Administrator Permissions --> Manage System Properties --> Company System and Logo Settings permission, you have enabled the data transfer tool through Admin Center --> Company System and Logo Settings --> Enable Individual Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment.
  2. You have the Administrator Permissions --> Manage Individual Talent Data Transfer permission to use the tool.
  3. You have the User Permissions --> General User Permission --> User Search permission for the specified target population.
  4. You have the Administrator Permissions Manage Hires --> Include Inactive Employees in the search permission to select inactive employments as the source for data transfer.
  5. You have the permission to view the status, title, and assignmentDisplayHeader (if you've configured the fields in the data modal) under User Permissions Employee Data   Employee Profile.
  6. The subject person for data transfer should have at least one inactive employment and one active employment.

Why It Matters

This important enhancement of Person-centric talent data transfers benefit organizations by ensuring uninterrupted access to comprehensive employee performance histories across transitions, enhancing data accuracy, reducing administrative workload, supporting compliance, and fostering agile, informed talent management. This approach strengthens employee engagement and retention by maintaining a continuous, unified view of their development and achievements.

Take Action

The transfer of talent data from an inactive to an active user ID can be tailored to align with your organizational requirements, enabling enhanced process agility and significantly reducing administrative burden through this advanced feature.

Start configuring today and experience the difference!

 

SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central 

SAP SuccessFactors HCM Core SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite

entry.title: Re: F110 : payment not possible because of reported error
entry.content:
Ol√°

Pode ser alguns casos dentre eles:

  • M√©todo de pagamento / house Bank incompat√≠vel ou ausente
    Mesmo com FBZP configurada, pode haver falta de combina√ß√£o v√°lida entre m√©todo de pagamento, banco conta banc√°ria e moeda. Se essa combina√ß√£o n√£o existe, o sistema n√£o consegue gerar o pagamento.
  • Aus√™ncia de m√©todo de pagamento v√°lido para os documentos (fatura/fatura aberta)
    Se os itens a pagar (faturas, notas) n√£o t√™m m√©todo de pagamento definido, mesmo que a FBZP esteja configurada, a proposta/pagamento pode falhar com erro gen√©rico.
  • Configura√ß√£o incorreta ou incompleta de ‚Äúdetermina√ß√£o autom√°tica de contas‚Äù (automatic account determination / GL accounts)
    Com novas company codes, talvez falte configura√ß√£o de contas cont√°beis relevantes (GL accounts) para determinados eventos ‚Äî sobretudo se h√° descontos, impostos retidos, ou transa√ß√µes especiais.
  • Itens bloqueados ou condi√ß√µes de sele√ß√£o n√£o atendidas
    Se h√° bloqueio no cadastro do fornecedor, na fatura, ou se os crit√©rios da execu√ß√£o de pagamento (data, moeda, limites m√≠nimos/m√°ximos, etc.)
  • Limites de valor m√≠nimo/m√°ximo para a forma de pagamento configurada
    A defini√ß√£o de faixas de valor para m√©todos de pagamento pode impedir o pagamento de valores fora de faixa, e esse tipo de bloqueio √†s vezes n√£o gera uma mensagem de erro clara.
  • Configura√ß√£o obrigat√≥ria de campos mestre de fornecedor n√£o preenchida
    Por exemplo: se na configura√ß√£o da forma de pagamento for obrigat√≥rio endere√ßo, banco, CEP, cidade, etc., e o fornecedor n√£o tiver esses dados, a sele√ß√£o falha.

entry.title: Month wise depreciation with Net book value and Remaining use ful life
entry.content:
I have asset RS. 100000

Depreciation should be calculated with netbook value and remaining useful life 4 years for each month seprately. Normally i saw system calculate depreciation year wise and then divide it 12.

I want to calculate as follow:

1st month: 100000 / (12 x 4 = 48 month) = 2083.33

2nd Month: NBV (100000-2083.33) = 97916.66 / (47 month) = 2083.33

3rd month: NBV (97916.66 - 2083.33) = 95833.33 / (46 Month) = 2083.33

4th Month: NBV (95833.33 - 2083.33) = 93749.97 / (45 Month) = 2083.33

 

So my requirement is that for each month, system should calculate not only netbook value but also remaining month wise, not year wise.

Thanks

entry.title: Entendiendo la Extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP: Parte 3
entry.content:
Como vimos en los primeros dos blogs Parte 1 y Parte 2, extender SAP Cloud ERP (o com√∫nmente llamado SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), es muy importante para adaptarse a la necesidad espec√≠fica de cada uno de tus clientes.

SAP Cloud ERP puede extenderse dentro de si misma, pero en esta parte final, abordaremos una de las formas √≥ptimas de escalar tu soluci√≥n y es, mediante el uso de la SAP Business Technology Platform o SAP BTP, mediante el dise√±o de aplicaciones Multi-tenant y multi-backend, para esto tenemos varios ejemplos dentro de los recursos oficiales de SAP, pero quiero mostrarles el que para m√≠, es el m√°s relevante para quienes desean comenzar en SAP Cloud ERP y tienen ya pr√°cticas en otro de nuestros productos, como SAP Business One o SAP Business ByDesign.

 

 

 

Proceso de desarrollo para un cliente a m√∫ltiples tenants y diferentes Back-ends

Empecemos an√°lizando lo siguiente: en tu empresa tienen una necesidad clara y deciden desarrollar una aplicaci√≥n espec√≠fica para un cliente, para ello puedes crearla directamente In-App, usando por ejemplo Key-user o Developer Extensibility en Cloud ERP.

Como segundo an√°lisis, quiero que revisemos lo que pasa, si te das cuenta que esa necesidad es la misma para otros usuarios, el camino entonces, es pensar en una soluci√≥n multi-tenant, que de hecho puede ser desarrollada dentro de SAP Cloud ERP, usando por ejemplo la Multi-off Delivery o la Scalable Delivery.

Ahora como tercer an√°lisis, ¬øqu√© pasa si te das cuenta que esa aplicaci√≥n no solo es √∫til para clientes de SAP Cloud ERP?, sino que tienes clientes de SAP Business One, SAP Business ByDesign, o incluso deseas poner la aplicaci√≥n como standalone solution y permitir el acceso a clientes que no cuentan con una de nuestras ERPs. All√≠ se hace muy relevante escalar nuestra aplicaci√≥n y usar la SAP BTP como centro de desarrollo y despliegue, nos referimos entonces a una aplicaci√≥n Multi-tenant y Multi-backend o de ERP agn√≥stico.

 

 

Modelos Operacionales

 

Como partner puedes tener diferentes modelos operacionales, uno de ellos es el modelo ‚ÄúCustomer Managed‚Äù donde los clientes gestionan directamente la implementaci√≥n y el mantenimiento de las soluciones, con el apoyo t√©cnico y consultoria del Partner.

Otro modelo es el ‚ÄúPartner SaaS Solutions‚Äù, donde el Partner desarrolla y gestiona aplicaciones de software como servicio (SaaS) en la nube, utilizando la plataforma SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). Este modelo permite a los Partners ofrecer soluciones escalables y compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP ERP, proporcionando a los clientes acceso a aplicaciones avanzadas y servicios como inteligencia artificial y machine Learning.

 

 

Partner Reference App: el caso de uso

 

La BTP Partner Reference App es un modelo, que te permite crear aplicaciones directamente en la SAP BTP, dise√±adas para ser compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP Cloud ERP, lo cual deja como resultado: f√°cil integraci√≥n y mantenimiento de la misma. Incluye ventajas de compatibilidad y eficiencia. El link general de esta aplicaci√≥n se encuentra publicado en nuestro GitHub  (BTP Partner Reference App).

La BTP Partner Reference app, sigue el modelo de soluciones de Software como Servicio para nuestros Partners. Al estar alojada en la SAP BTP est√° clasificada como una Side-by-side Extension, este tipo de aplicaciones son operadas desde esta plataforma y cuentan con ciclo de vida propio, independiente del ERP que se use.

Esta aplicaci√≥n es un imaginario de un Poetry Slam, donde el usuario debe imaginar que es un manager de eventos, quien organiza eventos de poes√≠a, y usa la aplicaci√≥n para planear y ejecutar los eventos, analizar los costos, comprar equipo, publicar los eventos, manejar las reservas, los visitantes y artistas.

 

Este modelo, sigue los est√°ndares SAP, con un modelo centralizado de identidad y autenticaci√≥n, un Launchpad com√∫n, navegaci√≥n entre aplicaciones y una integraci√≥n back-end segura. Tienes dos formas de acceder a esta aplicaci√≥n y probarla por ti mismo: la primera es ir directamente y clonar el repositorio de Github, o seguir paso a paso desde el desarrollo inicial hasta el modelo final. Si sigues el segundo paso la gu√≠a te llevar√° a:

 

1.     Crear el Core: donde el foco es la l√≥gica, los roles, los modelos y el contenido.

2.     Make it scale: all√≠ entender√°s como pasar de una soluci√≥n para un cliente a una multi-tenant

3.     Connect: Integra la soluci√≥n con tu ERP preferida

4.     Features: Agrega nuevas funcionalidades, a√±ade servicios, integra con elementos de terceros.

 

 

Tipo de Aplicaciones que pueden seguir este modelo

Pero ¬øC√≥mo saber qu√© tipo de aplicaciones pueden seguir este modelo?, aconsejamos este tipo de extensi√≥n cuando:

-    Son aplicaciones para un grupo separado de usuarios (Usuarios sin ERP)

-    Aplicaciones que deben tener proximidad a SAP BTP para el aprovechamiento de servicios como Machine Learning, AI entre otros.

-    Soluciones que deben ser integradas con diferentes ERPs y servicios en la nube.

 

 

Ventajas de este tipo de aplicaciones

¬øQu√© ventajas tienen este tipo de aplicaciones principalmente?

-    SAP standard para el desarrollo, experiencia de usuario y dise√±o

-    Mantener el Clean Core, que te permite acelerar la innovaci√≥n y estar siempre al d√≠a con actualizaciones.

-    Incluir Herramientas de Inteligencia artificial en tus soluciones.

 

 

Partner Journeys posibles

Seguir este modelo de arquitectura, permite tener un dise√±o que apoye diferentes caminos como Partners:

-    Un Partner de SAP Cloud ERP, puede crear IP que extienda la soluci√≥n

-    Un Partner Business One puede extender su negocio a SAP Cloud ERP

-    Un Partner ByD puede extender su soluci√≥n e IP a SAP Cloud ERP

-    Un Service Partner, puede crear una soluci√≥n escalable que por ejemplo provea a una gran compa√±√≠a con servicios a m√∫ltiples departamentos y subsidiarias.

 

 

Integraci√≥n con SAP Cloud ERP

 

 

Para la integraci√≥n con SAP Cloud ERP, es importante configurar el SAP Cloud Identity Services, y en la BTP el acceso de Trust Management, los servicios de Destino, entre otros servicios necesarios. Por el lado de SAP Cloud ERP, se deben configurar todos los canales de comunicaci√≥n, como Communication arrangement, Communication System, etc. , agregar la aplicaci√≥n como un ‚Äúcustom tile‚Äù y poder acceder a ella. 

El dise√±o de esta aplicaci√≥n permite la integraci√≥n en dos lineas, la primera Front-end que le permite navegar a la Aplicaci√≥n Poetry Slam Manager a los proyectos espec√≠ficos conectados en SAP Cloud ERP, y la integraci√≥n Back-end que permite crear un proyecto en SAP Cloud ERP y visualizarlo dentro de la aplicaci√≥n side-by-side mediante OData APis con el uso del principio de propagaci√≥n.

 

 

Extender tu aplicaci√≥n

En la √∫ltima versi√≥n de este ejemplo, tambi√©n se muestra la opci√≥n de adaptar este tipo de aplicaci√≥n para clientes espec√≠ficos, ya que hemos visto que aunque sea una soluci√≥n que resuelva un Problema de muchos clientes, cada cliente tiene sus propias necesidades y adaptarla tambi√©n genera robustez en la soluci√≥n.

Al ser una Cloud Application Programming model, o CAP, tambi√©n se pueden extender:

-    Campos

-    Entidades

-    Aplicaciones Web

-    APIs

 

 

Alcance del mercado al dise√±ar Multi-tenancy y ERP Agnogstic

Al aprovechar el dise√±o multitenant y ERP agnogstic, como partner de SAP, puedes aumentar significativamente el alcance del mercado. Este tipo de dise√±o permite que una sola instancia de aplicaci√≥n sirva a multiples tenants, lo que implica soluciones escalables y rentables a m√°s clientes, con la posibilidad de compartir servicios y disminuir costos. Adem√°s el dise√±o agn√≥stico, asegura que la aplicaci√≥n pueda ser f√°cilmente integrada a diferentes ERPs, no solo con los de SAP aumentando el atractivo de este tipo de aplicaciones y utilidad en diferentes entornos de clientes. Este enfoque mejora la penetraci√≥n del mercado y abre oportunidades para entregar soluciones a m√°s clientes independiente de la estructura ERP existente.

 

En estos tres blogs y en espa√±ol :P, hemos recorrido las diversas opciones para extender SAP Cloud ERP, destacando la importancia y las diversas formas de adaptar esta soluci√≥n a las necesidades de tus clientes. Espero que esta informaci√≥n haya sido √∫til y te haya proporcionado una visi√≥n clara de como escalar tus soluciones.

 

Me encantar√≠a saber que te pareci√≥ esta serie, Gracias por leerme.

 

S√≠guenos via @SAP and #S4HANA o encu√©ntrame en LinkedIn -> @Monica_Pimiento 

 

Saludos querido mundo SAP Hipanoparlante.

M√≥nica Pimiento

entry.title: Building the Future of Supplier Growth
entry.content:
For many years, we've heard from our customers: suppliers want more options, more opportunities, and more value. We listened to your needs and got to work. In Q1 2025, we landed an incredible milestone: launching the SAP Business Network, promote subscription, a new, one-of-a-kind subscription service designed to help suppliers show up stronger on the network, get discovered by the right buyers, and ultimately grow their businesses. 

This year wasn‚Äôt just about releasing new features. It was about laying the foundation for a modern, AI-enabled supplier experience that gives every business, regardless of size or tech maturity, the opportunity to stand out. 

Why We Built These Capabilities 

Supplier expectations are changing. Buyers are sourcing more strategically, relying on richer product data, and seeking partners who can demonstrate trust and authenticity in a sea of competition. Meanwhile, suppliers want more visibility, more control over how they present themselves, and more insights into how buyers engage with their profiles. 

Across industries and geographies, we heard a consistent message: 

‚ÄúHelp us put our best foot forward and help us understand what buyers are looking for.‚Äù 

This is the inspiration behind the product investments we made this year. 

What We Launched in 2024 

To support suppliers in showcasing their value and building new and stronger buyer relationships, we introduced several new capabilities as part of the SAP Business Network, promote subscription: 

Verified Profiles 

A new verification layer helps suppliers build trust with potential buyers by confirming key business information. Verified profiles stand out visually and give buyers confidence in the data behind them. 

AI-Generated Product Content 

Suppliers can now instantly create polished, buyer-friendly catalog content using generative AI. This helps standardize quality, reduce time spent on manual content creation, and ensure products appear in more relevant searches. 

Performance Insights 

Suppliers now have access to analytics that reveal how buyers engage with their profiles and catalogs. These insights highlight what‚Äôs working, what buyers are viewing, and where suppliers can strengthen their presence. 

AI-Based Profile Suggestions 

To help suppliers continuously improve, we introduced smart recommendations that identify missing information, highlight optimization opportunities, and guide suppliers toward a more complete and compelling profile. 

Together, these capabilities represent a major step forward in helping suppliers elevate their digital presence within the network. 

What We Learned This Year 

Launching a new supplier-facing product across a global network is no small feat, and we learned a lot along the way. 

  1. Quality supplier data is more important than ever 

Across every industry, buyers are prioritizing complete, accurate, and trustworthy information. Suppliers who invest in higher-quality profiles and catalog content are better positioned for visibility. 

  1. AI is a game-changer, especially for smaller suppliers 

Many suppliers told us they struggle to create or maintain robust product content. AI-generated descriptions and automated suggestions help level the playing field, giving every business access to professional-grade catalog data. 

  1. Suppliers want transparency into how buyers find them 

Suppliers want to know whether their profile is attracting views, which products buyers are clicking on, and how they can show up more effectively. Performance insights provide this invaluable detail to suppliers in an organized dashboard. 

  1. Supplier discovery is only as strong as the data behind it 

The more complete the profile and network catalog, the better the match. Everyone‚Äôs time is limited these days. By providing more complete data, SAP Business Network Discovery can provide higher quality matches, saving everyone time and reducing effort spent sorting through irrelevant matches by surfacing more relevant opportunities. 

What‚Äôs Coming in 2025 

This year was about building a strong foundation. Next year will be about scaling and expanding it. 

In 2026, we‚Äôre focused on: 

  • Enhancing the network catalog and profile user experience 
  • Continuing to strengthen verification and trust signals across the network 
  • Making it easier for suppliers to differentiate themselves and connect with new buyers 
  • Increasing supplier exposure during buyer sourcing and selection 

Our vision remains clear: 

Help suppliers grow with better visibility, better data, and better tools. 

Looking Ahead 

2025 marked an important step forward in creating a more powerful, modern supplier experience. We‚Äôre proud of the progress made and even more excited for what‚Äôs ahead. 

Thank you to all the suppliers who partnered with us this year, shared feedback, and pushed us to innovate. This is just the beginning. In 2026, we‚Äôll build on this foundation to unlock even more opportunities for suppliers across the network. 

Here‚Äôs to a year of growth and the groundwork for even more to come. 

Want to learn more?

If you're interested in learning more about how your business can grow on the network, contact us to schedule a 1:1 consultation with the Supplier Growth Team here or at suppliergrowth@sap.com.

To access more resources, including webinars, demos, blogs, and more, to help you get the most out of your account, check out our SAP Community page for suppliers.

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP BI Platform Support Tool 2.1.16 (Patch 16)
entry.content:
We have released a new maintenance patch for the SAP BI Platform Support Tool (BIPST), version 2.1.16.

This update is recommended for all users. The patch primarily focuses on maintaining stability and security by delivering important bug fixes and updated security components.

This version is compatible with BI 2025 and BI 4.3 +

In addition, this release includes a cleanup of several components that are no longer necessary or aligned with the current direction of the BI Platform. Removing these legacy features ensures the tool remains efficient, modern, and relevant for troubleshooting today‚Äôs environments.

Key Enhancements

1. Migration to SAP JVM 17

To maintain forward compatibility and improve security, the BI Platform Support Tool now runs on SAP JVM 17 (upgraded from the previous Java 8 runtime).

This modernization effort included updating underlying libraries and Java dependencies, resulting in two major benefits:

  • BI 2025 Readiness: The tool is now fully aligned for use with BI 2025 (while maintaining compatibility with BI 4.3).
  • Enhanced Security: Users now benefit from the security improvements and fixes delivered with the newer Java runtime.

2. New: Java SDK File Analyzer

This release introduces a new utility designed to help developers and administrators working with the BI Platform Administration SDK or Crystal Reports SDK‚Äîthe two types of BI Java SDK.

This tool scans any specified directory (including subfolders) to determine whether all required Java dependencies (.jar files) for a particular BI Java SDK version are present.

It compares the detected JAR files against the list documented in SAP Help:
SDK libraries in SAP Help Portal

The analyzer also highlights any extra or unexpected JAR files, as these can sometimes cause class conflicts or other issues during SDK development.

Please note:

  • This is an offline tool that analyzes directories locally on the host machine. It does not require a connection to BI Platform servers (CMS) or the Enterprise Repository.
  • This tool does not download or replace missing JAR files. Any required files must be obtained manually.
  • The tool is read-only and does not modify the directory it scans.

For detailed instructions, see the Java SDK File Analyzer documentation:
Java SDK File Analyzer ‚Äì Documentation

Deprecated Features

As the BI Platform continues to evolve, several older utilities within BIPST are no longer aligned with current technologies, browser support, or authentication frameworks. Version 2.1.16 removes the following components:

1. E2E Trace Wizard

This feature relied on deprecated Internet Explorer plug-in‚Äìbased workflows that are no longer supported.
End-to-End tracing has been a built-in feature of the Fiori BI Launchpad since BI 4.3.
For instructions, see KBA 2726569.

2. SAML Authentication Configuration Wizard

Trusted Authentication and SAML configuration have changed significantly in BI 4.3 SP04 Patch 10 and BI 2025, and the legacy wizard is no longer compatible with the new authentication model.

Furthermore, for BI versions up to 4.3 SP04 Patch 9, we observed very limited usage of this wizard. Each customer‚Äôs SAML implementation requires landscape-specific steps and validation, making the generic workflow provided by the wizard no longer meaningful. As a result, the value of updating or maintaining this component was minimal.

For instructions on configuring Front-End SAML Authentication on BI 4.3 / 2025, please refer to KBA 2791348.

3. Screen Recorder

Removed due to the availability of more advanced and widely accessible screen-recording tools (including built-in OS tools and open-source utilities).

4. Passport Decoder

No longer required due to the shift toward Fiori Launchpad E2E tracing workflows.

5. Webi Doc Masker

Deprecated because it is no longer used in current BI support scenarios.

6. Deprecated Tabs in Landscape Report

The following tabs have been removed from the Landscape Report comparison views:

  • Explorer
  • Dashboard Cache
  • Dashboard Processing

These components are deprecated within the BI Platform and are no longer maintained.

Fixed Issues

1. Change Analysis Page Hanging

Previously, comparing two landscape reports that included non-standard authentication types could cause the Change Analysis page to hang when selecting the root Authentication object.
This issue has been resolved in this patch.

2. Improved README Instructions

The README.txt file (attached below) has been refreshed with clearer, step-by-step instructions for both Linux and Windows, making installation and execution easier for administrators.

Download & Quick Troubleshooting

The latest version is available in the SAP for Me Software Center:
Direct Download link: BIPST 2.1.16

Windows Installation Steps

  1. Extract the downloaded .zip file and run BISupportToolSetup.exe.
  2. To start the BI Support Tool, run win_launch_bipst.bat.
  3. Wait a few seconds for the tool to initialize.
  4. If you encounter issues launching the tool, logging in, or saving a landscape report, delete the folder:
    C:\Users\<your_user>\AppData\Roaming\BISupportTool
    Then re-run win_launch_bipst.bat.

Linux Installation Steps

1. Extract the tool
unzip BISupportToolSetup.exe

This will create a directory named BISupportTool.

2. Set permissions
chmod 755 -R .
3. Create configuration file

Create a file named landscape.json and paste the template from the README.txt located under .../BISupportTool/README.txt.
Update the following fields only:

  • Hostname
  • BI_user
4. Run configuration step
./linux_launch_bipst.sh -autoconfig=/full/path/to/landscape.json -password=YourPassword
5. Run the tool
./linux_launch_bipst.sh -autorun

Note: On Linux, the tool is limited to generating landscape reports. Other utilities and features are only available on Windows.

We Want Your Feedback

Please feel free to share your thoughts and feedback in the comments below.
For suggestions on future enhancements, feature requests, or issues to report, reach out through the available SAP Support channels.

entry.title: Employee Replication as Vendors in S/4 Public Cloud
entry.content:
I have a client who uses SuccessFactors and is currently transitioning from ECC to S/4 Public Cloud. Due to client requirements, we are leveraging scope ID JB1 to integrate SuccessFactors and S/4.

Today, my client does not maintain employee payment details in SuccessFactors and only maintains this data in ECC. They also use program RPRAPA00 which creates an SM35 batch job to handle the creation of employees as vendors. Given program RPRAPA00 is no longer available in S/4 Public Cloud, we would be unable to leverage what they do today. Also, since they do not maintain payment information in SuccessFactors, we are unable to leverage the standard functionality available as part of JB1.

With all that in mind, I am looking for assistance in solving two problems:

  1. How can we accomplish the initial replication of employees where they get created as vendors? I thought about plugging standard values for all records in the API but that would create issues with any future payments based on what is populated in the supplier master. 
  2. How can we load the legacy employee vendors from ECC with their bank/payment details and then link it to the BP created through the SuccessFactors integration?

entry.title: Bringing the SAP Fiori Development Portal and Its Use to the Next Level (6 of 6)
entry.content:
As we conclude our mini-series on the SAP Fiori development portal, where we provided you with everything needed to make the best possible choices for your project, it is now up to you to pick your set of building blocks and decide where to use what for your targeted SAP Fiori app. Let's consolidate key learnings that will help you maximize the portal's potential in your development workflow and look at the way forward.

Transform how you approach SAP Fiori app development

The SAP Fiori development portal represents more than just documentation - it's a comprehensive platform that transforms how you approach SAP Fiori app development. Whether you're a seasoned developer, a business analyst defining requirements, or a designer crafting user experiences, the portal provides real-time exploration options for building apps based on SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 to make informed decisions and build enterprise-grade applications efficiently.

Now it's time to consolidate what we've learned into actionable guidance that will help you maximize the portal's potential in your development workflow.

Tips and Tricks for Maximum Productivity

It is all about balancing standardization with customization. The portal structure and feature help you navigate the SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 options to maximize your success.

Portal Structure

The portal structure supports you in balancing standardization with customization.

  • Map business requirements to building blocks first - use the portal to identify which components can address your function needs out-of-the-box 
  • Leverage Global Patterns early in your project planning - these non-visual building blocks like draft handling and navigation patterns are often overlooked but critical for enterprise applications‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ
  • Evaluate standard floorplans against your use cases before building custom solutions - List Report and Object Page patterns handle the majority of business scenarios. Together with the extension points provided by SAP Fiori elements, they can often meet your requirements with minimal effort
  • Use Custom Pages for more creative app layouts - if the target picture of your application is too far from the standard floorplans, opt for custom page creation using building blocks and global patterns to get the benefits of the metadata-driven UIs, or leverage freestyle SAPUI5 to achieve your goal.

Portal Features

  • Use "Show Code" consistently - every page offers this feature to reveal the underlying annotations and implementation details
  • Experiment with live code editing - modify annotations in real-time to understand how changes affect the UI behavior. Switch off live mode for more complex code changes
  • Explore both display and edit modes - many building blocks behave differently in these modes, and the portal shows both scenarios
  • Follow "Documentation" links for detailed product documentation - the portal provides focused overviews while official docs offer comprehensive details

The Portal as Your Companion

The SAP Fiori development portal isn't just a reference - it's an active participant in your development process, already starting when designing the target picture. When mapping the business user needs to how this translates into application UI, you want to review the options in the SAP Fiori development portal since following standard patterns or use standard building blocks will reduce implementation and maintenance efforts drastically. By including the portal in your everyday development process, you'll find that it becomes an indispensable tool for delivering high-quality SAP Fiori applications efficiently.

As the portal continues to evolve, these fundamental approaches will serve you well. The combination of hands-on experimentation, systematic evaluation, and informed decision-making creates a development workflow that scales with your team's growth and adapts to changing business requirements.

While using it in your day-to-day work, help us understand what helps you the most, where things go in the right direction but lack the last mile, and inspire us for things we haven't even thought about yet.

Looking Forward ‚Äì SAP Fiori elements is compatible with AI tooling

The SAP Fiori development portal represents our commitment to making SAP Fiori elements development more accessible, efficient, and collaborative. That also includes using its content and the learning when providing AI-based development support by SAP Fiori tools. As we continue to enhance the portal, remember that it's designed to grow with your expertise.

We can think in the following directions right now:

  • Enhance the level of detail for developers, e.g. . This also make makes the portal useful as a grounding document for AI tools and LLMs that assist developers with creating SAP Fiori elements apps
  • Include the designer persona much more - bridging to the SAP Design System for the basics and providing guidance for the use of available features of SAP Fiori elements based on the context
  • Connect the explorer world of the portal with the implementation world of SAP Fiori tools

Whether you're building your first SAP Fiori application or extending an existing enterprise solution, the portal provides the foundation for making informed decisions that balance rapid development with enterprise-grade quality. The building blocks, patterns, and guidance we've explored throughout this series are your tools for creating applications that users love and businesses depend on.

Thank you for joining us on this journey through the SAP Fiori development portal. We're excited to see the innovative applications you'll build using these tools and techniques. And maybe you are already one of the next customers presenting how the portal helped you in crafting your SAP Fiori app in the SAP Fiori development roundtable. Your feedback and experiences will continue to shape the portal's evolution, making it an even more powerful resource for the entire SAP Fiori development community.

Complete Blog Series Overview

To get the full overview of the SAP Fiori development portal, check out the following blog posts of the mini-series:

  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6)
  • Get familiar with SAP Fiori development portal and the power of the building blocks (2 of 6)
  • Explore the potential of SAP Fiori development portal using complex building blocks (3 of 6)
  • Use SAP Fiori development portal to understand extension options for standard floorplans (4 of 6)
  • Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
  • Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)
